pros: Great students, nice facilities, great location; benefits are good and the time off and retirement plans are very generous.
cons: Administration, organization, structure; several employees who are deeply set in their ways because they have worked there since the 80s, 90s, or earlier. Staff members are frequently treated poorly and reminded how expendable they are. Long hours and years of work are not valued over 'favorites' in the office. Only time staff is praised or thanked for work is when they retire or if they save/generate money for the college. Little to no investment in the growth or development of human capital (employees). Not a place to work long-term; get in, get experience, and get out! Worked hard and felt like none of it was noticed or mattered to anyone.

pros: Front row student interaction. Fellow faculty are understanding and kind.
cons: Administration frequently disregards faculty concerns. Faculty salary/compensation is stagnant. Administration refuses to discuss/negotiate salary. Faculty are not peer reviewed by outside universities. Faculty development is not funded with high regard and very limited. Courses taught by faculty outside their professional/educational background. Many traditional Registrar and Admissions department roles are delegated to an already taxed faculty. Most interested in catching students while letting quality of education drop.
